name: DUTCH DEFENSE
idea: The most aggressive reply to 1.d4! With ...f5, Black immediately fights for e4 and prepares a kingside attack. There are two main setups: the Stonewall (...d5, ...e6, ...c6, ...Bd6) with a solid pawn wall, or the Leningrad (...g6, ...Bg7, ...d6) with the fianchetto. Both lead to unbalanced, fighting positions. It's the opening for players who want to attack as Black!
errors_white: Ignoring Black's kingside attack: ...g5, ...h5 can be dangerous
Playing e4 without preparation: ...fxe4 can be good for Black
Being too passive: White must use the center and the e5 square
errors_black: Weakening the King too much: f5 and g5 leave the King exposed
Playing ...e5 at the wrong time: can leave the f5 pawn weak
development: Nf6 is essential - controls e4 and prepares ...Ne4 after 0-0
e6 supports f5 and frees the Bf8 - Stonewall structure
Be7 (solid) or Bd6 (aggressive, targets h2) depending on system
Castle quickly! The h5-e8 diagonal is weak, the King must be safe
The Dutch problem! Comes out via d7-e8-h5 or stays passive
The ...g5-g4 push is the main attack plan - open the g-file

traps.name: Queen Trap
traps.desc: 2.Qh5+?! looks strong but after ...g6 3.Qh4 (or Qh3) Black plays ...Nf6 and the Queen is misplaced. AVOID (Black): Don't panic! ...g6 then normal development.

traps.name: Staunton Gambit
traps.desc: 2.e4!? Staunton Gambit - pawn sacrifice to open lines. After ...fxe4 3.Nc3 Nf6 4.Bg5 White has activity. AVOID (Black): Accept with ...fxe4 then ...d5! to close the center.

traps.name: Bishop Trap
traps.desc: In the Leningrad, if White plays h3?! Black prepares ...g5-g4! opening the g-file. AVOID (White): Play Qc2 or Bf4 instead to control e4 without weakening the kingside.

variants.name: Stonewall
variants.uci: d2d4 f7f5 c2c4 g8f6 g2g3 e7e6 f1g2 d7d5 g1f3 c7c6
variants.white_plan: Black's center is solid but the Bc8 is bad. Play b3/Bb2, Qc2 and look to exchange the bad Bishop or break with e3-e4.
variants.black_plan: Wall of pawns d5-e6-f5! The Knight goes to e4 via d7. Plan: ...Bd6, ...Qe7, ...Ne4, then kingside attack.

variants.name: Leningrad
variants.uci: d2d4 f7f5 c2c4 g8f6 g2g3 g7g6 f1g2 f8g7 b1c3 e8g8
variants.white_plan: Double fianchetto. White plays Nf3, 0-0, d5 (closes the Bg7) or Rb1/b4 for queenside attack.
variants.black_plan: The Bg7 is a monster! Plan: ...d6, ...Nc6, ...e5 (if possible) to open the diagonal. Attack ...g5-g4 if opportunity arises.

variants.name: Classical
variants.uci: d2d4 f7f5 c2c4 g8f6 b1c3 e7e6 g1f3 f8e7 c1g5
variants.white_plan: Classical development. The Bg5 pin bothers Black. Plan: e3, Bd3, Qc2, 0-0 then look for e4 at the right moment.
variants.black_plan: Play ...0-0, ...d6, ...Qe8 (frees the Queen for h5) and prepare ...Ne4 or ...e5. The Bishop comes out via d7-e8.
